file_metadata.title: Brief Local Application of Progesterone via a Wearable Bioreactor Induces Long-Term Regenerative Response in Adult Xenopus Hindlimb

chunks.text: Adult Xenopus laevis frogs can regenerate improved limbs using a wearable bioreactor containing progesterone, showing improvements at molecular, anatomical, and behavioral levels after just a 24-hour treatment.
chunks.chunk_summary: Brief progesterone treatment via a wearable bioreactor enhances limb regeneration in adult Xenopus frogs.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study addresses the challenge of limb repair in adult vertebrates by characterizing a drug delivery device for severed hindlimbs in adult Xenopus laevis. A 24-hour application of a progesterone-releasing bioreactor induced paddle-like regenerates, analyzed using molecular markers, morphometrics, X-ray imaging, immunofluorescence, and behavioral assays. This model allows testing therapeutic cocktails, demonstrates progesterone's pro-regenerative effects, and validates brief, device-based drug delivery for long-term regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: A progesterone-releasing bioreactor promotes significant limb regeneration in adult Xenopus laevis after a short exposure.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Limb and organ repair is crucial, with millions affected by amputations.  Ideal solutions would trigger in vivo limb-building pathways. Despite research on regeneration mechanisms, rebuilding lost limbs in non-regenerative animals remains challenging, highlighting the need for a tractable vertebrate model. Many animals regenerate appendages, unlike humans, despite genetic similarities. Xenopus laevis, like axolotls, regenerates limbs, but this ability declines developmentally, resulting in hypomorphic cartilage spikes in later stages. Previous work induced tail regeneration in non-regenerative Xenopus using systemic drug cocktails targeting bioelectric states, but this approach is limited due to widespread bioelectric signaling. This study aims to develop targeted small-molecule delivery in adults for localized, brief interventions to improve regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study aims to improve limb regeneration in adult Xenopus using targeted drug delivery to overcome limitations of systemic approaches.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: A wearable bioreactor has shown positive effects on regeneration. Progesterone (Prog) is a neurosteroid with potential for nerve regeneration and tissue remodeling, modulating inflammation for wound healing, angiogenesis, and bone remodeling.  Prog also regulates bioelectric cell state via ion flux, and bioelectric signaling drives regeneration and patterning in Xenopus and other models.  This study investigates whether a Prog-containing silk device improves cellular dynamics and regenerative potential after hindlimb amputation in adult Xenopus, due to Prog's effects on neural and non-neural tissue and bioelectric signaling.
chunks.chunk_summary: Progesterone's potential for nerve regeneration, tissue remodeling, and bioelectric signaling modulation makes it a candidate for enhancing limb regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study analyzes the regenerative effects of a combined treatment (cocktail + delivery method) on adult Xenopus hindlimbs. A brief 24-hour exposure modifies blastema transcriptional networks and induces sustained regenerative changes. This platform allows testing "master regulator" therapeutics, where brief treatments initiate long-term growth and remodeling. The findings show adult Xenopus limb growth and morphogenesis potential, providing a roadmap for interventions to improve complex appendage regeneration in vertebrates.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study investigates the long-term regenerative effects of a brief, targeted progesterone treatment in adult Xenopus limbs.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The progesterone receptor (PR) is present in adult Xenopus limb tissue, particularly in the bone marrow, epithelial tissue, and connective tissue. A fluorescent ligand for PR and hormone displacement assays confirmed PR expression. Co-staining with DAPI showed binding sites primarily in bone marrow mesenchymal cell nuclei. Progesterone effectively displaced the fluorescent ligand, while hydrocortisone did not, confirming PR specificity. ELISA showed significantly increased progesterone levels at the blastema after 24 hours of bioreactor exposure, but not in blood or brain, demonstrating localized drug delivery.
chunks.chunk_summary: Progesterone receptors are present in adult Xenopus limbs, and the bioreactor effectively delivers progesterone locally to the amputation site.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The progesterone-loaded bioreactor modified cell response and tissue remodeling during early regeneration. At 0.5 months post-amputation, treated animals showed irregularly oriented cells in the subepithelial area, unlike the fibrous scar in controls. While proliferation wasn't significantly increased, immune cell distribution differed, with more XL2+ cells proximally and fewer distally in treated animals. At the bud-outgrowth stage (2.5-3 mpa), proliferation was similar between groups. Treated animals appeared to have more major blood vessels, and organized nerve bundles were observed, unlike the irregular nerve fibers in controls.
chunks.chunk_summary: The progesterone bioreactor alters early regenerative responses, including cell organization, immune cell distribution, and nerve patterning.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The combined treatment altered anatomical outcomes and bone remodeling over 9.5 months. Macroscopic differences appeared early, with delayed wound healing in treated animals. At 2.5 mpa, treated regenerates became cone-shaped, unlike the thin-rod shape in controls. Treated animals developed paddle-like structures, while controls formed spike-like regenerates. X-ray images showed robust bone outgrowth in treated animals, significantly different from controls at 2.5 and 5 mpa.  Bone growth plateaued at 7.5 mpa, with two distinct regions: proximal weakly ossified bone and distal non-ossified bone/cartilage. The bone swelling coincided with pigmented epidermis, while immature bone remained under unpigmented epithelium.
chunks.chunk_summary: The progesterone treatment leads to significant differences in anatomical outcomes and bone remodeling, resulting in paddle-like structures instead of spikes.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: At 9.5 mpa, control regenerates showed cartilaginous spikes with minimal bone growth, while treated animals exhibited complex structures like paddles, spurs, and thick spikes, accompanied by bone outgrowth. Morphometric analysis revealed broader regenerates with less curvature in the treated group. A composite regenerative index (RI) showed significant differences between groups at 2.5 and 9.5 mpa, with treated animals having higher scores. Regenerates stopped growing after 5-7.5 mpa, reaching the length of the tibiofibula plus tarsus, corresponding to the digit location in uncut limbs.
chunks.chunk_summary: Treated animals developed complex, patterned regenerates with significant bone outgrowth, achieving a higher regenerative index than controls.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The 24-hour progesterone treatment induced long-term cellular and tissue changes in the regenerate tips. Treated regenerates showed a larger specialized surface with organized nerves and vessels, unlike the peripheral localization in controls.  Treated tips had more and larger nerve bundles and blood vessels. Comparing neurovascular patterns to uncut limbs revealed that treated regenerates were closer to the intact limb, particularly the distal region, in terms of nerve organization and blood vessel morphology.
chunks.chunk_summary: The progesterone treatment resulted in improved neurovascular patterning in the regenerate tips, resembling that of intact limbs.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The combined treatment induced molecular changes consistent with digit formation. Shh and Hoxd13, genes involved in digit identity and patterning, showed broader expression patterns in treated regenerates, forming multiple spots along the distal edge, compared to the single, restricted expression in controls. This suggests the treatment promotes molecular changes associated with digit development.
chunks.chunk_summary: The treatment induced changes in Shh and Hoxd13 expression patterns, suggesting the potential for digit formation.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Locomotor activity was assessed in treated and untreated animals. Treated animals showed activity levels closer to those of uncut animals, with significantly more active movements and surfacing frequency.  Analysis of time spent in different tank quadrants revealed significant differences, with treated animals exhibiting more unbiased exploration.  Mean swimming speed was also closer to uncut animals in the treated group, indicating improved functional recovery.
chunks.chunk_summary: Treated animals demonstrated improved locomotor activity, resembling uncut animals more closely than untreated controls.
chunks.authors: ["Celia Herrera-Rincon", "Annie S. Golding", "Kristina M. Moran", "Hayley Carabello", "Justin A. Guay", "Julia Zaltsman", "David L. Kaplan", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: RNA sequencing revealed molecular mechanisms underlying the treatment's long-term effects. Comparing transcriptomes of control, sham, and treated blastemas showed 66 differentially expressed genes between sham and control, and 531 between treated and control.  Sham treatment downregulated genes like NADH dehydrogenase and upregulated SMAD4 and olfactory receptors.  The combined treatment downregulated neuropeptides and signaling molecules like prolactin and arginine vasopressin, while upregulating genes like histone H2B and superoxide dismutase 3. Subnetwork enrichment analysis showed 150 enriched networks after sham treatment and 190 after combined treatment, indicating distinct molecular pathways involved.
chunks.chunk_summary: RNA sequencing identified numerous differentially expressed genes and enriched networks, revealing distinct molecular pathways activated by the progesterone treatment.
